title: Monitor & Control Project Work
description: Analyze work performance data into information through variance analysis and corrective actions.
objectives: Understand Monitor (measure performance) vs Control (take action)
Calculate Schedule, Cost, and Scope variances
Distinguish corrective actions (fix current) from preventive actions (prevent future)
Apply tolerance thresholds to decide when action is needed
Transform work performance DATA into INFORMATION

screens.headline: 75% Complete. Electrical 10% Behind. HVAC $7K Over Budget. Are We On Track?

dialogue.text: Give me a status update! Are we on track?

screens.learningHook: How do you turn observations into decisions? When does a variance require corrective action vs just monitoring?

screens.title: Variance Analysis & Action Decisions
screens.instructions: Calculate variances, categorize actions, and decide when to act.

options.text: All three areas show variances requiring assessment

feedback.correct: Perfect! Schedule -10% (behind), Cost +$7K (over), Scope -4 people (short). All variances require assessment.
feedback.incorrect: Review: Variance = Actual - Baseline. Negative schedule = behind. Positive cost = over budget. Fewer delivered = scope gap.

scenarios.title: Stage 2: Corrective vs Preventive Actions
description: Categorize each action as fixing current problems or preventing future ones.

items.label: Review HVAC estimates for FUTURE work
Hire 2 more line cooks to meet baseline
Reduce equipment quality to absorb overrun
Create inspection checklist for future work

feedback.correct: Excellent! Corrective = fix NOW (1,3,5). Preventive = avoid FUTURE problems (2,4,6).
feedback.incorrect: Corrective fixes existing problems. Preventive prevents future ones. Both are needed.

scenarios.title: Stage 3: Tolerance Decisions
description: Schedule: Critical path impacts require action
Scope: Deliverables for opening must complete

questions.question: Which variances require IMMEDIATE corrective action?

options.text: Electrical (10% behind, critical path) → CORRECTIVE ACTION
HVAC ($7K over, 0.6% of budget) → IMMEDIATE CORRECTIVE ACTION

feedback.correct: Perfect! Electrical = critical path, must fix. HVAC = within 5%, monitor. Staffing = can defer to grand opening.
feedback.incorrect: Assess each against tolerance. Critical path delays require action. Within-tolerance variances can be monitored.

content.insight: Monitoring without controlling = observation without action. Both are required.

corrective.purpose: Bring current performance back to baseline

content.note: Both are types of change requests.

content.principle: Not all variances require action—only those exceeding tolerance.

correct.text: You've identified the variances correctly. Now you can make informed decisions about which ones need action.
I wanted to fix everything immediately. But you showed me: Electrical is critical (fix it), HVAC is within tolerance (monitor), staffing can wait. Prioritize based on impact.

screens.title: Software Project Variance Analysis
screens.context: Software project: 12 features in 6 months, $600K budget. At Month 4: 6 features done (planned 8), $420K spent (planned $400K), 15 defects (threshold: 10).

screens.title: Monitor & Control Mastery
screens.summary: Transform work performance data into information through variance analysis, then decide when corrective action is needed.
takeaways: Corrective = fix current, Preventive = prevent future
Not all variances require action—assess against tolerance

artifacts.title: Variance Analysis Dashboard Template
artifacts.description: Calculate and track schedule, cost, scope variances

characterClosing.text: Monitoring identifies variances. Controlling responds to them. Don't just measure—act when variances exceed tolerance.
